subject: History and Economics
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course?

My desire to study the combination of history and economics stemmed from my mother teaching me about Japanese colonialism in Korea. What intrigued me most was how Japanese imperialism created contested legacies over East Asia that still shape political tensions today.?
This curiosity deepened after Dr. Kim's lecture on Japanese colonial rule, which showed how policies like Japanese-language schooling and the land survey programme subverted everyday life, standardizing ownership as well as allowing extraction. What struck me was how these measures were not just administrative but transformative, altering education, property rights and cultural identity.
I explored the economic aspect further through Betty L. King's article which analyzed Japan's investment in infrastructure, particularly railways, as both a tool of economic control and driver of modernization. I was fascinated by this ambiguity: did colonialism lay foundations for Korea's later development, or impose obstacles that Koreans had to overcome? Studwell's 'How Asia Works' helped me view the question more comparatively. His analysis of land reform and state industrialization as responsible for East Asia's growth suggested that Korea's post-liberation success was more due to its own policies than colonial structures. Comparing this with the Philippines, which lacked such reforms, led me to conclude that Japanese rule imposed as many obstacles as it left institutions, and that Korea's later growth was achieved despite, not because of, colonialism.
What fascinates me most is how these contested legacies remain central to international relations today, with historical memory shaping political debates between Japan and Korea.?
How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course?
Studying the French Revolution at A-Level drew me to how liberal and nationalist ideas spread across Europe which I developed further in the Julia Wood Essay Competition where I evaluated the significance of the 1848 Revolutions. While A.J.P. Taylor rejected them as 'the turning point at which history failed to turn', I argued that their significance lay in reshaping political culture. Despite their immediate failure, I learnt from Christopher Clark's lecture that the revolutions embedded ideas of popular mobilization and reframed political debates. I found this idea more compelling as it better accounts for how temporary liberal spaces in Prussia allowed nationalist and liberal ideas to circulate more freely, creating networks and political culture that contributed to Germany's unification. Reflecting on this taught me to look beyond immediate outcomes and focus on long-term impacts.
That same approach shaped my engagement in economics. I was intrigued by the question of how beneficial privatization and liberalization truly was to efficiency and growth, leading to an interest in their real-world consequences in the 'transition recession' of the 1990s. I first engaged with this in the Rybczynski Prize where I concluded that the depth of the recession was not an unavoidable feature of post-communist liberalization but a result of policy design. Aslund argued that rapid reforms were necessary to stabilize currencies and avoid worse collapse, shown by Poland's quick recovery. However, I found Stiglitz's critique that shock therapy deepened contraction in 'Globalisation and its Discontents' more convincing as it explained why many states like Russia and Ukraine's GDP took almost ten years to recover. Seeing how GDP collapse, hyperinflation and rising poverty undermined trust in new institutions convinced me that rushing reforms without safeguards led to avoidable consequences.
What else have you done to prepare outside education and why are these experiences useful?
In school, I have roles as a Finance Society lead where I have run sessions on the history of financial crises, as well as a maths mentor and careers committee member. A large part of my life also involves volunteering shown by last summer, when I spent time with the child refugees at St Mary's Ukrainian School which introduced me to traditional meals, culture and history.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My desire to study the combination of history and economics stemmed from my mother teaching me about Japanese colonialism in Korea. What intrigued me most was how Japanese imperialism created contested legacies over East Asia that still shape political tensions today.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The opening is described as fine but also kind of nothing and obvious. The tutor notes that recent colonialism would naturally lead to tensions, so this observation is not particularly insightful. A more direct approach would be preferable.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Go straight into the topic by saying a particular part of history that interests you is the impacts of Japanese imperialism in South Korea, being much more specific without the roundabout introduction.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This curiosity deepened after Dr. Kim's lecture on Japanese colonial rule
feedback_items.your_feedback: You cannot bring in a random person without properly sourcing them. Who is Dr. Kim? This needs proper citation and context.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Properly identify and source Dr. Kim with their full credentials or institutional affiliation.

feedback_items.weak_passage: What struck me was how these measures were not just administrative but transformative, altering education, property rights and cultural identity.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This insight is weak and makes no sense. Who said these policies were just administrative? If Japanese-language schooling changes education to Japanese, it's naturally altering education. These policies are meant to change these things by nature, so calling them transformative is just describing them doing their job, not providing real insight.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of this weak observation, provide another sentence or two explaining further impacts and how these policies fundamentally changed the culture and history.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was fascinated by this ambiguity: did colonialism lay foundations for Korea's later development, or impose obstacles that Koreans had to overcome?
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a big, strong question that demands an answer in the next couple of sentences. The tutor expected specific facts about how colonialism contributed to development or created obstacles, with data showing actual impacts. Instead of an answer, you jump to another book reference.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Answer the question with facts: explain how colonialism contributed to growth of specific industries or policies, or detail the obstacles created with supporting evidence and data showing what would have happened without those policies.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studwell's 'How Asia Works' helped me view the question more comparatively.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What does more comparatively mean in this context? The phrase is unclear and doesn't provide specific information about how the book changed your thinking.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain specifically how the comparative approach in the book changed your perspective or methodology.

feedback_items.weak_passage: His analysis of land reform and state industrialization as responsible for East Asia's growth suggested that Korea's post-liberation success was more due to its own policies than colonial structures. Comparing this with the Philippines, which lacked such reforms, led me to conclude that Japanese rule imposed as many obstacles as it left institutions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The logic jumps confusingly. You're suddenly discussing East Asia broadly, then jumping to the Philippines without clear connection. Korean development is one of the most studied areas in development economics over 50 years, and you're reducing it to this oversimplified conclusion. You cannot give this level of conclusion with this weak level of reasoning and support. The tutor compares this to saying you've proved God exists because a Bible may have existed and been read by some people.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide much stronger evidence and reasoning. Explain specifically which reforms are being discussed, why the Philippines comparison is relevant, and build a properly supported argument before drawing such a strong conclusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying the French Revolution at A-Level drew me to how liberal and nationalist ideas spread across Europe which I developed further in the Julia Wood Essay Competition where I evaluated the significance of the 1848 Revolutions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: After mentioning liberal and nationalist ideas spreading across Europe and the essay competition, you should expand on what the significance was. The tutor wants to know what you argued and how the 1848 revolutions affected things.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what significance you identified in your essay. Detail how the revolutions affected the spread of ideas and what you were trying to argue.

feedback_items.weak_passage: While A.J.P. Taylor rejected them as 'the turning point at which history failed to turn', I argued that their significance lay in reshaping political culture.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The logic is lacking and doesn't naturally follow. The argument hasn't been proven enough for you to confidently reject A.J.P. Taylor's viewpoint. The tutor notes they're not claiming to be an expert in this area, but even reading it, the reasoning doesn't follow naturally.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Strengthen your argument with more evidence before claiming to disagree with an established historian. Prove your point more thoroughly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was intrigued by the question of how beneficial privatization and liberalization truly was to efficiency and growth, leading to an interest in their real-world consequences in the 'transition recession' of the 1990s.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutor is not totally sure what this is talking about. The opening of this economics section lacks clarity.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reframe this more clearly. State that following the fall of communism there was a deep recession, then explain that the size and significance of the recession was not inevitable and could have been mitigated through intelligent policy design.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The depth of the recession was not an unavoidable feature of post-communist liberalization but a result of policy design.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is quite an obvious statement. Where have you gotten the idea that someone was arguing it was unavoidable? The framing needs work.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reframe by discussing how following the fall of communism there was a deep recession, then explain specific ways it could have been prevented through policy design, comparing to cases where similar situations occurred.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Seeing how GDP collapse, hyperinflation and rising poverty undermined trust in new institutions convinced me that rushing reforms without safeguards led to avoidable consequences.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutor can see what you're trying to say, but it's not written well and not argued very well. The logic doesn't follow properly.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use more of the source material and argue the point more clearly and effectively.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The statement overall is described as a summary of random notes with no real development. There are no real insights drawn, it doesn't flow well together, and the logic is flawed in several areas. It needs a fair bit of work to reach a satisfactory level. The tutor notes this wouldn't be in the top 50% of economics statements.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Given you attend a top sixth form (St. Paul's or City), the expectations are higher. You need to critically evaluate what you've written and ask yourself if you've actually made points or just written things. Develop arguments more thoroughly, ensure logical flow, and draw real insights from your reading.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The content is actually different from other economics statements which tend to focus on game theory and other areas of development. The content is unique and really interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Keep the unique content focus but reframe and argue and develop these ideas significantly better.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In school, I have roles as a Finance Society lead where I have run sessions on the history of financial crises, as well as a maths mentor and careers committee member. A large part of my life also involves volunteering shown by last summer, when I spent time with the child refugees at St Mary's Ukrainian School which introduced me to traditional meals, culture and history.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This extracurricular section is fine but could probably be shortened by a sentence or two through more efficient language if you need more space in other areas.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense the language to save space for developing the main academic content.

subject: History and Economics
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course?

I am fascinated by how institutions shape societies, whether through colonial legacies, revolutionary upheavals or economic transitions. My interest began with the impact of Japanese imperialism in Korea. Betty L. King's article showed how railways and banks, appearing to modernize, were in fact tools of extraction that restricted Korean enterprise. This led me to the deeply contested debate over whether colonialism laid the foundations for Korea's growth or created obstacles to overcome.
Michael Kim's lecture on Japanese occupation gave me a more concrete answer by examining everyday policies. Japanese-language schooling erased Korean language and undermined cultural continuity. Access to higher education was barred, leaving Korea in 1945 with few trained professionals which hindered growth.
The land survey programme dispossessed farmers without documents, raising tenancy rates above 70% by the 1930s. High rents discouraged tenants from investing in productivity and embedded rural inequality. This suppressed domestic demand and diverted capital to Japan.
Only after 1945, with land reform and the re-Koreanisation of education, did South Korea build the foundations of later growth. These examples convinced me that institutions, not colonial policies, underpinned later growth.
I want to study History and Economics to understand how institutions shape lives, and why people can view the same past so differently.
How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course?
The French Revolution first drew me to how revolutionary ideas spread across Europe which I explored by evaluating the significance of the 1848 Revolutions. A.J.P. Taylor's view that 1848 was a 'turning point at which history failed to turn' was persuasive as monarchies survived and most uprisings failed, until Christopher Clark's lecture and Revolutionary Spring shifted my perspective. He argued that even failed uprisings reshaped political culture by forcing regimes to confront demands for constitutions, rights and national self-determination. Once the ideas were voiced, they could not be erased.
The Frankfurt Parliament demonstrated this. Though its Constitution was rejected, the debates over monarchy, federalism and rights created a model later used in German unification. Similarly in Italy, Piedmont's Statuo Albertino survived after defeat, keeping it a constitutional monarchy while others reverted to absolutism. These cases taught me to look beyond immediate collapse to long-term institutional shifts.
I applied the same approach to economics. After communism collapsed, recessions in Eastern Europe were often seen as unavoidable while others argued the severity could have been mitigated through policy design. Stiglitz's Globalisation and Its Discontents showed that the depth of collapse in the 1990s depended on policy sequencing and institutions.
In Russia, shock therapy liberalized prices and privatized firms before regulatory frameworks existed. GDP fell by 40%, unemployment soared and oligarchs seized state assets, leading to a later recovery reliant on oil and gas rather than effective structures. Poland also liberalized rapidly under the Balcerowicz Plan but under stronger institutions, an independent central bank and integration with EU markets. GDP fell in 1990-91 yet growth resumed by 1992, making Poland the first post-communist economy to recover.
Comparing these paths convinced me that transition outcomes were not inevitable. Both states liberalized quickly but weak institutions and poor sequencing created Russia's 'lost decade' while Poland's institutional strength enabled stability and growth. I realized political choices determine whether reforms succeed or deepen crisis.
What else have you done to prepare outside education and why are these experiences useful?
In school, I have roles as a Finance Society lead where I have run sessions on the history of financial crises, as well as a maths mentor and careers committee member. A large part of my life also involves volunteering; last summer, when I spent time with the refugees at St Mary's Ukrainian School, I was introduced to traditional meals, culture and history.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The French Revolution first drew me to how revolutionary ideas spread across Europe which I explored by evaluating the significance of the 1848 Revolutions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You say revolution three times in this sentence. The writing is not succinct. The rest of your writing uses first drew me to and explored which is basically the same thing, then evaluating the significance - when broken down like this there is nothing in this sentence. Each sentence should be densely packed with specific and clear insights.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Make the writing more succinct and avoid repetition. Combine redundant phrases and pack the sentence with actual insights rather than just describing actions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: A.J.P. Taylor's view that 1848 was a 'turning point at which history failed to turn' was persuasive as monarchies survived and most uprisings failed, until Christopher Clark's lecture and Revolutionary Spring shifted my perspective.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not a fan of using quotes from books unless they must be taken verbatim for some deeper reason. Otherwise it comes across as you being lazy or not able to understand or interpret the writing to its key points. In this case there is no reason for that section to be directly quoted.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be more direct. Say I first read [author] who argued that the 1848 Revolutions was not a turning point because x monarchies survived and x uprisings failed. However, Christopher Clark's lecture gave me another perspective to consider.

feedback_items.weak_passage: He argued that even failed uprisings reshaped political culture by forcing regimes to confront demands for constitutions, rights and national self-determination.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fine.
feedback_items.strong_passage: He argued that even failed uprisings reshaped political culture by forcing regimes to confront demands for constitutions, rights and national self-determination.
feedback_items.why_strong: This sentence is considered fine with no issues.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Once the ideas were voiced, they could not be erased.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fine, maybe attach this to previous sentence with semi-colon since ideas are very connected so it will sound cleaner.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Attach to the previous sentence with a semi-colon for better flow.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Though its Constitution was rejected, the debates over monarchy, federalism and rights created a model later used in German unification.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fine but becoming a bit list-like.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be careful not to make the writing too list-like. Develop analysis rather than just listing examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Similarly in Italy, Piedmont's Statuo Albertino survived after defeat, keeping it a constitutional monarchy while others reverted to absolutism.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fine but getting more list-like.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move away from listing examples and provide deeper analysis.

feedback_items.weak_passage: These cases taught me to look beyond immediate collapse to long-term institutional shifts.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This doesn't make that much sense. I can puzzle together what you mean but not ideal for a first-time read through if the person doesn't have to give you the benefit of the doubt. Why were you looking at immediate collapse vs other effects anyway? Surely you should demonstrate better critical thinking than that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Write a better conclusion that makes clear sense and demonstrates stronger critical thinking.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I applied the same approach to economics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What approach? Unclear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify which approach you're referring to.

feedback_items.weak_passage: After communism collapsed, recessions in Eastern Europe were often seen as unavoidable while others argued the severity could have been mitigated through policy design.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not loving the direction of logic here. It should be more like collapse of a regime causes recessions and then the argument is about how best to mitigate. Nobody is sitting there saying unavoidable let's just leave that alone which is what yours currently reads as.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reframe the logic to show that regime collapse causes recessions, then the debate is about mitigation strategies.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Stiglitz's Globalisation and Its Discontents showed that the depth of collapse in the 1990s depended on policy sequencing and institutions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You must expand on this point and explain exactly what is meant by that, otherwise you are just namedropping. There are so many interesting insights in this book, choose a proper one.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Write: In Globalisation and its Discontents, Stiglitz offers one view that the severity of the 1990s crash was in part due to policy sequencing and institutions, then expand with specific details about what this means.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In Russia, shock therapy liberalized prices and privatized firms before regulatory frameworks existed.
feedback_items.your_feedback: UK spelling is liberalised and privatised - consider changing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use UK spelling conventions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: GDP fell by 40%, unemployment soared and oligarchs seized state assets, leading to a later recovery reliant on oil and gas rather than effective structures. Poland also liberalized rapidly under the Balcerowicz Plan but under stronger institutions, an independent central bank and integration with EU markets. GDP fell in 1990-91 yet growth resumed by 1992, making Poland the first post-communist economy to recover.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is becoming too much of a list of places. You need to sit and develop a theory or idea. You're just telling a story about what happened. This is all reading like a series of events with no critical analysis, higher level understanding, or evaluation. Even though technically fine in content, tutors will likely just skim this section - not a red flag just not a plus point.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move beyond storytelling. Develop critical analysis, demonstrate higher level understanding, and evaluate the significance of these events rather than just describing them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Comparing these paths convinced me that transition outcomes were not inevitable. Both states liberalized quickly but weak institutions and poor sequencing created Russia's 'lost decade' while Poland's institutional strength enabled stability and growth. I realized political choices determine whether reforms succeed or deepen crisis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not a bad conclusion to be fair, but you haven't analyzed well enough to get to this conclusion.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Build stronger analysis throughout the paragraph to support this conclusion.

subject: History and Economics
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course?

My interest in the relationship between institutions and development was piqued when I read about the impact of Japanese imperialism on Korea's economy. A Betty L. King article showed me that railways and banks, which appeared to modernize Korea, were in fact tools of extraction that restricted Korean enterprise. This led me to the deeply contested debate over whether colonialism ultimately supported Korea by laying the foundations for growth or created more obstacles. Eckert's Offspring of Empire and his studies on colonial industry claim that while politically oppressive, imperialism was the catalyst for Korea's growth which showed me how contested the issue is.
Michael Kim's lecture on Japanese occupation suggested that everyday policies like Japanese-language schooling reduced Korean literacy and limited access to higher education; by 1945, Koreans held fewer than 5% of skilled professional positions, leaving the country without the doctors, engineers or administrators needed to drive development. The land survey programme transferred land from farmers with no documented ownership to Japanese firms, pushing tenancy rates to 70% by the 1930s. High rents discouraged tenants from productive investment and entrenched rural inequality. Much of the rice surplus was exported to Japan, limiting domestic consumption and ensuring rural profits served Japanese rather than Korean markets.
After 1945, reforms reversed these patterns. Land redistribution created a class or smallholders who invested in productivity and the re-Koreanisation of education expanded access to skilled jobs. These policies strengthened equity and human capital, laying the institutional foundations for rapid growth. This showed me that it was the transformation of institutions after independence, rather than colonial policies that underpinned Korea's growth.
How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course?
The French Revolution first drew me to how revolutionary ideas spread across Europe which I explored by evaluating the significance of the 1848 Revolutions. A.J.P. Taylor's view that 1848 was a 'turning point at which history failed to turn' was persuasive as monarchies survived and most uprisings failed, until Christopher Clark's lecture and Revolutionary Spring shifted my perspective. He argued that even failed uprisings reshaped political culture by forcing regimes to confront demands for constitutions, rights and national self-determination. Once the ideas were voiced, they could not be erased.
The Frankfurt Parliament demonstrated this. Though its Constitution was rejected, the debates over monarchy, federalism and rights created a model later used in German unification. Similarly in Italy, Piedmont's Statuo Albertino survived after defeat, keeping it a constitutional monarchy while others reverted to absolutism. These cases taught me to look beyond immediate collapse to long-term institutional shifts.
I applied the same approach to economics. After communism collapsed, recessions in Eastern Europe were often seen as unavoidable while others argued the severity could have been mitigated through policy design. Stiglitz's Globalisation and Its Discontents showed that the depth of collapse in the 1990s depended on policy sequencing and institutions.
In Russia, shock therapy liberalized prices and privatized firms before regulatory frameworks existed. GDP fell by 40%, unemployment soared and oligarchs seized state assets, leading to a later recovery reliant on oil and gas rather than effective structures. Poland also liberalized rapidly under the Balcerowicz Plan but under stronger institutions, an independent central bank and integration with EU markets. GDP fell in 1990-91 yet growth resumed by 1992, making Poland the first post-communist economy to recover.
Comparing these paths convinced me that transition outcomes were not inevitable. Both states liberalized quickly but weak institutions and poor sequencing created Russia's 'lost decade' while Poland's institutional strength enabled stability and growth. I realized political choices determine whether reforms succeed or deepen crisis.
What else have you done to prepare outside education and why are these experiences useful?
In school, I have roles as a Finance Society lead where I have run sessions on the history of financial crises, as well as a maths mentor and careers committee member. A large part of my life also involves volunteering; working with Ukrainian refugees reminded me that institutional resilience is not only a historical question but a pressing issue in today's crises.

The rest of your writing uses first drew me to and explored which is basically the same thing, then evaluating the significance - when broken down like this there is nothing in this sentence. Each sentence should be densely packed with specific and clear insights.

subject: History
statement_full_text:
History, both as a study and a process, is the crux of our society the Vietnam War. A crucial point in the midst of the post-war global political climate, the Vietnam War  causations and consequences but also its wider scope and how it relates further to our past and present.  encapsulate what the twentieth century was all about; battles of ideology, proxy wars, and imperialism disguised as defending a feigned 'honour'.  not just the military or political history of the conflict, but also how it forces us to confront contested narratives about morality and responsibility. This war was the climax point of a century of ideological war that was rooted in colonialism, which dates back to as far as the mid-nineteenth century, the French conquest of Dai Nam. The fact that our actions in the present can result in turmoil more than a century later is what allows the study of history to remain so pertinent today. This interest in the Vietnam War led me to my EPQ, titled, To what extent did the Vietnam War reshape American society, politics, and national psychology?. I examined various academic journals, and books such as The Cold War and Vietnam by George C. Herring, American Studies in Vietnam: Past and Present by Le Thi Thu Hang, which discuss how Vietnamese studies were altered after the war, how Vietnam has been shaped as a country since the war's end, and how American Studies have been cemented in Vietnam, displaying the ramifications our history has on the present motivates me to delve into the subject further at university.

whether America was most to blame for the Cold WarI looked more into the history of Cuba pre-1959 and completed an independent research project on the exploitation and manipulation of the US in Cuba. Discovering how events intersect with societal aspects of life further ignited my passion for History. I then attended a lecture at SOAS University by Dr. Andreas Krieg on the Gaza War, which further delved into the societal aspects of these conflicts and how they can, intentionally or not, have  society and people. This angle of History was further explored in my A-Level coursework studying Russia from 1855-1964, prompting me to attend a lecture by Historian Christopher Read on Lenin 

Over the course of Year 12, I participated in the Mayor of London Future Leaders scheme. This enriching course empowered me to advocate for equality and diversity, and stand against hate and intolerance. It also honed my analytical and research skills, as I explored case studies of social and political change, the causes and effects of policy decisions, and how leadership shapes societies. Undertaking work experience at the Health Policy Partnership and speaking to various members of the team provided a real insight into working life. I spoke to people individually and got first-hand experience on how to conduct high-quality analysis and research of academic literature. Additionally, I learnt about parts of medicine and health policy that evolved over time, and the historical paradigm shifts about the understanding of health policy a lecture by Dr. Cassandra Quave at Emory University Paradigm Shifts in the History of Medicine I learnt more about germ theory, the works of Louis Pasteur and Robert Koch, and how Koch's postulates became cemented in our history.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This is not technically how you write a personal statement for Oxford. The main issue is that it's just a descriptive piece of text, not an academic explorative personal statement. It's just listing out stuff. The entire first paragraph makes no actual points - it's almost entirely filler.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start with a question in history that would interest a history academic. Say what you first thought based on A-level knowledge, then explain how a reading gave you another perspective. Discuss the perspective, why it's interesting, some source material used, and why it's persuasive. Show constant back and forth of exploring subject, demonstrating interest, and proving you would enjoy exploring, researching and debating topics at university without just taking things as given.

feedback_items.weak_passage: History, both as a study and a process, is the crux of our society. And I love the way the study of a singular historical event can act as a doorway to so much more.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not personally a fan of this kind of filler start. The tutor prefers statements that begin like I read this book and found this point really interesting, but understands if you want to keep it as filler. However, you then carry on with more filler.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider cutting this opening filler and starting directly with substantive historical content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Take the Vietnam War, for example. This is a crucial point in the post-war global political climate. It's fascinating because of its complex causations and consequences.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're giving a summary but not telling the causations and consequences. If you're going to mention complex causations and consequences, you need to actually explain them. You can't just give a summary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: After stating it's fascinating, immediately explain the specific causations and consequences rather than just describing them as complex.

feedback_items.weak_passage: and how it relates further to our past and present
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're not planning on telling what the wider scope is. You're not going to tell how it relates to further past and present. The reader is just supposed to read your summary and be like OK cool, you've got a great summary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Actually explain the wider scope and specific connections to past and present, don't just mention they exist.

feedback_items.weak_passage: It encapsulated what the 20th century was all about. Battles of ideology, proxy wars, and imperialism disguised as defending a feigned honour.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Says who? Where are you getting that from? Was that from a book? Was that from a lecture? You need to tell where this claim comes from.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cite the source for this interpretation of the 20th century.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Not just the military or political history of the conflict, but also how it forces us to confront contested narratives about morality and responsibility.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What narratives? Are you going to tell the narratives? Are you going to give examples? Are you going to tell specifically what all of that means? This is just description.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify which contested narratives you're referring to and provide concrete examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This was the climax point of a century of ideological war that was rooted in colonialism, which dates far back to the French conquest of Dana.
feedback_items.your_feedback: All of that so far was just nothing, and the reader is supposed to just believe you about this being the crux and forcing us to confront things with absolutely no evidence, no reasoning, no support.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide evidence and reasoning immediately rather than making unsupported claims.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The fact that our actions in the present can result in turmoil more than a century later is what allows the study of history to remain so pertinent today.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're writing this like you're writing a book about history. This is not a book about history. This is an exploration into how you, what you find interesting in history and how you have begun to explore it beyond A level.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on your personal exploration and analysis rather than making grand statements about history's importance.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This interest in the Vietnam War led you to an EPQ. I examined various academic journals, and books such as The Cold War and Vietnam by George C. Herring, American Studies in Vietnam: Past and Present by Le Thi Thu Hang, which discuss how Vietnamese studies were altered after the war, how Vietnam has been shaped as a country and how American studies have been cemented in Vietnam.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Now we're finally getting into something tangible you've done. You give the title but instead of giving your reasoning, arguments, and interesting conclusions or perspectives you came across whilst doing the EPQ, you're just telling that you examined various journals. What is the reader supposed to take from that - that you can read? There's no indication whether you can read, analyze, and pick out pertinent points. Instead of bringing out good perspectives, you're just describing what is in those journals. All of this is just facts, just a narrative you're presenting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain your actual reasoning, arguments, and conclusions from the EPQ. Discuss interesting perspectives you encountered and how they shaped your thinking, not just what topics the sources covered.

feedback_items.weak_passage: displaying the ramifications our history has on the present motivates me to delve into the subject further at university
feedback_items.your_feedback: What ramifications are you supposed to believe? Because you're saying it shaped a country and American studies have been cemented in Vietnam. Is that the ramifications you're talking about? That doesn't feel that big unless you're going to explain it. What is this that motivates you? Are you talking about the ramifications being on the present? It's not clear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clearly specify which ramifications you mean and why they are significant enough to motivate further study.

feedback_items.weak_passage: After winning this debate whether America was most to blame for the Cold War, I looked more into the history of Cuba and completed a research project.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're not going to tell what the debate was or what you argued. Are you going to tell what sources you used or what your conclusion was? No. You're just going to say discovering how events intersect with societal aspects of life ignited your passion.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what you argued in the debate, what sources you used, and what conclusions you reached in your research project.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Discovering how events intersect with societal aspects of life further ignited my passion for History.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutor will know you love history if you talk about history and the ideas in it, what you found and what you learned. You don't have to keep saying sentence after sentence that history is the crux of society, history does this, this is why I want to study it, this motivates me. You've used at least 5 or 6 sentences like this throughout - that's 15-20% of your personal statement just saying you're motivated to study the subject.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut these motivational statements and replace with proof through actual discussion of historical ideas and analysis.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I then attended a lecture which delved into the societal aspects of these conflicts and how they can intentionally or not have impact directly or indirectly on society and people.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is the most vague sentence in the world. Which delved into societal aspects of these conflicts and how they can intentionally or not have impact directly or indirectly on society and people - you realize that's the most vague, nothingy sentence you could have written. From what was presumably a pretty interesting lecture that you attended, you're not showing it whatsoever.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide specific details from the lecture - what particular societal impacts were discussed, what evidence was presented, what new perspectives you gained.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This angle of history was further explored in your coursework. Nothing about the coursework, it just prompted you to attend a lecture, and then the lecture again, you're just gonna give me a summary that it was about the impact.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't explain anything about the coursework or what impact the Russian revolution had on the people of Russia. It was presumably really interesting but the reader will never know.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what you learned from the coursework and what specific impacts were discussed in the lecture about Lenin and the Russian Revolution.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutor is worried this was too harsh but feels it's necessary given the Oxford deadline. The statement is not bad but not as analytical or developed as it should be. It's lacking a key critical analytical portion. Given limited time before Oxford deadline, this is fine but if you want to make changes, this is the feedback.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Transform the statement from descriptive to analytical. Show your thought process, engagement with historiography, and ability to critically evaluate different perspectives rather than just summarizing topics you've studied.

subject: Law
statement_full_text:
KCL LSE UCL Warwick 

1. Why do you want to study this course or subject? 

My  interest  in  law  was  inspired  by  Professor  Daniella  Lock's  seminar  on  protest  law, 
provided  by  King's  College  London's  K+  programme.  Exposed  to  areas  of  public  and 
criminal  law,  I  created  an  academic  poster  on  the  impacts  of  protest  law  in  the  UK   and 
delivered  a  presentation  to  spread  awareness  on  how  liberty  was  declining  due  to 
parliamentary  sovereignty.  I  understood  that   International  agreements  like  the  European 
Convention  on  Human  Rights (ECHR), embodied the values of a civil society by protecting 
the  freedom  for  assembly  and  expression.  However  legislation  passed by parliament such 
as  the  Police,  Crime,  Sentencing  and  Court  Act  2022  limited  citizens  rights  as  law 
enforcement widened their criteria for restricting protests. Originally protests were restricted 
in order to prevent "disorder, damage and disruption". With the new law, "impact" was added 
to  the  criteria.  This  change  arguably  promoted  unfair  and  exploitative  practices  by  law 
enforcement as the right to descent could be silenced by the interpretations of individuals. In 
reading  Michael  Head's  book  "Democracy,  Protest  and  the  Law:  Defending  a  democratic 
right",  the  notion  of  the  right  to  protest  being  an  indispensable  safeguard  for  democracy 
resonated within me. Nevertheless, was this "safeguard" truly effective? and could we refine 
the  legal  system  by  allowing  the  supreme  court  to  veto  bills incompatible with the ECHR?  
These opinions drew me closer to the study of law as I found myself forced to find solutions 
to issues impacting society. 

Question 2: 

Studying political events such as the Rwanda Bill furthered my interest in public law. 
Although the Rwanda Bill violated Article 3 of the ECHR, the Supreme Court was unable to 
block the Bill from being passed. To me, this event was indicative of a legal system that 
disregards the authority of an uncodified constitution. A.V. Dicey's description of 
parliamentary sovereignty explained how and why Parliament was commanding of 
legislation. The legal system, therefore, continues to enable governments in dismantling 
human rights, as laws are unentrenched. Nevertheless, I saw the merits of an uncodified 
constitution, as it facilitates the adaptation of laws in accordance with the evolution of 
society. My curiosity led me to watch the Oxford Union debate, "Should We Codify the British 
Constitution?" Sir Robert Buckland argued on whether it was necessary to change our 
organic constitution, as well as the impossibility of crafting laws without loopholes. I 
understood his perspective, but I did not see the impossibility of a perfect legal system as a 
reason to avoid revamping the constitution. Conversely, Professor Randy Barnett argued 
that a codified constitution fulfilled what contract theorists called the "deliberate function". 
Reflecting on my research, I saw a codified constitution not only as a deterrent to dictatorial 
rule but also as a way of empowering citizens through convenient access to the law. At 
university I hope to learn about how the Supreme Court's abilities are limited due to its 
power being bestowed by parliament. 

 
Q3: 

My internship at the corporate law firm Macfarlanes made me keen to understand how the 
principles of law are upheld across different disciplines. I saw the landmark ruling Uber BV v 
Aslam as a means of maintaining worker rights in receiving a minimum wage. The 
implications this had on gig economy businesses could be seen through  increased 
operational costs. My internship taught me the importance of firms acting in the spirit of the 
law and not just following  profit chasing sentiments. However legal loopholes mean firms 
can reclassify job roles in order to restructure contracts, therefore keeping profits. 
Furthermore  lobbying poses the question of whether it is ethically right for laws which are 
meant to uphold justice to  simply be bought. I believe Reform is on the horizon and in 
studying law I can further question our legal system and take steps towards limiting 
bureaucratic reach in society.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall this is one of the better statements the tutor has come across this season, especially considering if you're at an underperforming state school and did a lot of this yourself. You're a really good writer who gets straight to the point with clarity, no vagueness, and well-developed points. Most of it reads very well.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: The suggested changes are minor tweaks rather than major revisions. The statement is already strong.
feedback_items.strong_passage: The overall clarity, directness, and development of ideas throughout most of the statement
feedback_items.why_strong: The writing is clear with no vagueness, points are well-developed, and the student gets straight to the point effectively.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Exposed to areas of public and criminal law
feedback_items.your_feedback: Exposed to just sounds a bit funny and random. It's unclear exactly how you were exposed to it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Put something more specific like I then went on to do something, or I then found out about public and criminal law.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I created an academic poster on the impacts of protest law in the UK and delivered a presentation
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not sure what an academic poster is or what value that brings. You might want to go straight into the presentation content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider combining the poster content into the presentation and just say the presentation covered both things - the impacts of protest law and how liberty was declining.

feedback_items.weak_passage: These opinions drew me closer to the study of law as I found myself forced to find solutions to issues impacting society.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole conclusion sentence is weak. First, you don't need a conclusion. Second, saying you found yourself forced to find solutions is too strong from what you described. It's unclear how you've been forced to find solutions. It's a bit unnecessary and random.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut, change, or rethink this conclusion. Consider whether opinions should be reframed as questions instead.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The second paragraph is really nice and really well developed. It's definitely your strongest paragraph.
feedback_items.strong_passage: The entire second paragraph about the Rwanda Bill, parliamentary sovereignty, and constitutional debates
feedback_items.why_strong: This paragraph shows strong development, clear argumentation, and demonstrates genuine engagement with complex legal issues.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The implications this had on gig economy businesses could be seen through increased operational costs.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a random conclusion. Is there any other point you could touch upon there? Something more developed than just increased operational costs.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Find a more developed point about the implications, perhaps something that better demonstrates your understanding of the case's significance.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My internship taught me the importance of firms acting in the spirit of the law and not just following profit chasing sentiments. However legal loopholes mean firms can reclassify job roles in order to restructure contracts, therefore keeping profits.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutor thought you would explain how the internship taught you to act in the spirit of the law, but then you talk about legal loopholes for reclassifying jobs, so it doesn't carry on very well. The bit about legal loopholes and reclassifying jobs comes out of nowhere. It looks like you dropped in knowledge you found interesting when you were there and thought you'd shove it in somewhere, but it doesn't quite work.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Put in an example. Say in recent news there's been a case where a job was reclassified and used to cut a worker in this particular case. Then you can say this is typical of law firms to do even though they're supposed to act in the spirit of the law. That would be more complete as a point.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Furthermore lobbying poses the question of whether it's ethically right for laws which are meant to uphold justice to simply be bought.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This suddenly brings in lobbying without clear connection to what came before.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Build a clearer connection to how this relates to your internship experience or the previous discussion of legal loopholes.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I believe reform is on the horizon and in studying law I can further question our legal system and take steps towards limiting bureaucratic reach in society.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not a big fan of that conclusion sentence. It doesn't add a lot. It's just a catch-all to be like I know what law is, I really want to do this, but you don't need it. You've already explained that well throughout your personal statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this sentence and expand somewhere else instead.

feedback_items.your_feedback: On GCSEs: not a problem because your grades which you've got (6 sevens) and they usually only look at the top 6 subjects. Because you've got contextual factors, your sevens are basically 8s and 9s, and 8s and 9s are considered the same. So you have top GCSE grades essentially, and you've got good predicted grades. This part is not a problem whatsoever.
You don't have to put in any of these changes. It's still good, it's still a very strong statement. These are just points if the tutor were being very picky.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: The changes suggested are optional refinements to an already strong statement.
